subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}

Two hands, each handing an object to another.

subSections.title: Etymology 1
subSections.text:
From {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*g-la}}.

{{zh-ref|Zhao (1990)}} argued {{cog|nan|予|tr=hō͘||to give; to allow; by}} is a {{der|zh|qfa-tak}} substrate, associating it with {{cog|za|hawj||to give; to allow}} and {{cog|pcc|haec||to give; to allow}}. Note both were descended {{inh|th|tai-pro|*haɰᶜ||to give}} which originated from either {{der|th|ltc|-}} {{ltc-l|許|to allow}} or {{der|tai-pro|och|-}} {{och-l|與|id=2|to give}} ({{zh-ref|Zheng (2008)}}). 

{{zh-ref|Zheng (2008)}} considered the ''h-'' initial of both {{cog|nan|予|tr=hō͘||to give; to allow; by}} and {{cog|za|hawj||}} to be descended from the Chu dialect ({{lang|zh|楚方言}}) of {{der|tai-pro|och|-}} {{och-l|與|id=2|to give}}, and noted instances where words beginning with the {{zh-l|*以|}} initial in Middle Chinese are pronounced with a ''h-'' initial in modern Min. The rimes of {{cog|nan|予|tr=hō͘}} and {{cog|za|hawj||}}, on the other hand, descended from the rimes of {{zh-l|*與}} during Qin/Han and in an authoritative southern dialect in the Southern dynasties respectively.

Taiwan's Ministry of Education agrees that the original character representing {{cog|nan|予|tr=hō͘||to give; to allow; by}} is indeed {{lang|zh|予}} ({{zh-l|*與|to give}} and {{zh-l|*予|to give}} are from the same root), but considers the Xiamen, Zhangzhou and Taiwan pronunciation ''hō͘'' to be the result of sound change from Quanzhou pronunciation ''thō͘'' ([https://twblg.dict.edu.tw/holodict_new/iongji/pdf/annesia327pdf.pdf Source]).
